PyMC

pymc_model

Module: pymc_model.py

Summary:

Base class for PyMC-based football match prediction models.

Dependencies:

  • abc.abstractmethod

  • ast.Dict

  • typing.Optional, Union

  • numpy as np

  • pandas as pd

  • pymc as pm

  • pymc_experimental.model_builder.ModelBuilder

  • bundesliga.settings

  • bundesliga.model.base_footballmodel.FootballModel

class bundesliga.model.pymc.pymc_model.PymcModel(model_options: Dict | None = None, team_lexicon: Dict | None = None)

Bases: ModelBuilder, FootballModel

Base class for PyMC-based football match prediction models.

Provides a simple framework to build, train, and predict football match outcomes using PyMC. Inherits from ModelBuilder and FootballModel, and includes methods for configuration, data handling, and model evaluation.

abstract build_model(X: DataFrame, y: Series, **kwargs)

Constructs the PyMC model using the provided data.

Subclasses must implement this method to define the model’s structure.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – Input features, expected to include ‘home_id’ and ‘away_id’ columns.

  • y (pd.Series) – Target data representing outcomes (e.g., goals).

  • **kwargs – Additional configuration parameters.

static get_default_model_config() → dict

Returns a class default config dict for model builder if no model_config is provided on class initialization. The model config dict is generally used to specify the prior values we want to build the model with. It supports more complex data structures like lists, dictionaries, etc. It will be passed to the class instance on initialization, in case the user doesn’t provide any model_config of their own.

Returns:

Default model configuration.

Return type:

dict

static get_default_sampler_config() → dict

Returns a class default sampler dict for model builder if no sampler_config is provided on class initialization. The sampler config dict is used to send parameters to the sampler . It will be used during fitting in case the user doesn’t provide any sampler_config of their own.

Returns: dict: Default sampler configuration.

property output_var

Returns the name of the output variable for the model.

Returns:

The name of the output variable (e.g., “goals”).

Return type:

str

predict_goals(test_data: ndarray | DataFrame | Series, extend_idata: bool = False, **kwargs) → DataFrame

Predicts the goals for home and away teams using the trained model.

Parameters:

  • test_data (Union[np.ndarray, pd.DataFrame, pd.Series]) – Input data for predictions.

  • extend_idata (bool, optional) – Whether to extend the inference data. Defaults to False.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for prediction.

Returns:

A DataFrame containing the predicted goals for home and away teams.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

predict_toto_probabilities(predictions, **kwargs) → DataFrame

Predicts the probabilities of match outcomes (toto) based on predicted goals.

Parameters:

  • predictions (pd.DataFrame) – A DataFrame containing predicted goals for home and away teams.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for prediction.

Returns:

A DataFrame containing the probabilities for:

  • Team 1 winning (index 0),

  • Team 2 winning (index 1),

  • A draw (index 2).

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

train(X, y, **kwargs)

Trains the PymcModel using the provided data.

Prepares the target data and fits the model using the configured sampler settings.

Parameters:

  • X – Input features for training.

  • y – Target data for training.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for training.

Returns:

The inference data object containing the results of the training.

Return type:

idata

version = '0.1'

pymc_simple_model

Summary:

Implementation class for PyMC-based football match prediction models.

Dependencies:

  • numpy: For numerical computations and random number generation.

  • pandas: For data manipulation and handling of input datasets.

  • pymc: For probabilistic programming and Bayesian model specification.

  • bundesliga.settings: For configuration parameters, including the random seed.

  • bundesliga.model.pymc.pymc_model: The base class (PymcModel) that this model extends.

class bundesliga.model.pymc.pymc_simple_model.SimplePymcModel(model_options: dict, team_lexicon: DataFrame)

Bases: PymcModel

A simple Bayesian model for forecasting football match outcomes using PyMC.

This class builds a probabilistic model that estimates team-specific offensive and defensive strengths based on match data. By leveraging Poisson likelihoods, it models the number of goals scored in a match, ensuring that the computed mean values remain above a minimal threshold. The model is configurable through external model options, and it utilizes a team lexicon to map team identifiers to their respective attributes.

team_lexicon

A mapping of team identifiers to team names or indices used within the model.

_model_type

A string identifier for the type of model implemented (“Simple_FootballModel”).

Type:

str

version

The version identifier of the SimplePymcModel implementation.

Type:

str

build_model(X: DataFrame, y: Series, **kwargs) → None

Build and configure the PyMC probabilistic model for predicting football match outcomes.

This method prepares and constructs the Bayesian model by first preprocessing the input data. It extracts the necessary features (specifically, the home and away team identifiers) from the provided DataFrame, and converts the target data into an appropriate format. The method then sets up mutable data containers within a PyMC model context to hold these inputs. Using prior parameters from the model configuration (such as offensive and defensive means and variances), it defines normal priors for team strengths. The model calculates expected goal rates for both home and away teams, ensuring that these rates do not fall below a minimum threshold by using a conditional switch. Finally, the observed match outcomes (goals) are modeled using a Poisson likelihood, thereby completing the model specification.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame containing match features. It must include ‘home_id’ and ‘away_id’ columns that denote the identifiers for the home and away teams, respectively.

  • y (pd.Series) – The target data representing observed goal counts, provided as a pandas Series.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for customizing the model configuration, if necessary.

version = '0.1'

pymc_toto_model

Summary:

Implementation class for PyMC-based football match prediction models.

Dependencies:

  • numpy: For numerical computations and random number generation.

  • pandas: For data manipulation and handling of input datasets.

  • pymc: For probabilistic programming and Bayesian model specification.

  • bundesliga.settings: For configuration parameters, including the random seed.

  • bundesliga.model.pymc.pymc_model: The base class (PymcModel) that this model extends.

class bundesliga.model.pymc.pymc_toto_model.TotoModel(model_options: Dict | None = None, team_lexicon: Dict | None = None)

Bases: PymcModel

A simple Bayesian model for forecasting football match outcomes using PyMC.

This class builds a probabilistic model that estimates team-specific offensive and defensive strengths based on match data. By leveraging Poisson likelihoods, it models the number of goals scored in a match, ensuring that the computed mean values remain above a minimal threshold. The model is configurable through external model options, and it utilizes a team lexicon to map team identifiers to their respective attributes.

team_lexicon

A mapping of team identifiers to team names or indices used within the model.

_model_type

A string identifier for the type of model implemented (“Simple_FootballModel”).

Type:

str

version

The version identifier of the Totomodel implementation.

Type:

str

build_model(X: DataFrame, y: Series, *args)

Build and configure the PyMC probabilistic model for predicting football match outcomes.

This method prepares and constructs the Bayesian model by first preprocessing the input data. It extracts the necessary features (specifically, the home and away team identifiers) from the provided DataFrame, and converts the target data into an appropriate format. The method then sets up mutable data containers within a PyMC model context to hold these inputs. Using prior parameters from the model configuration (such as offensive and defensive means and variances), it defines normal priors for team strengths. The model calculates expected goal rates for both home and away teams, ensuring that these rates do not fall below a minimum threshold by using a conditional switch. Finally, the observed match outcomes (goals) are modeled using a Poisson likelihood, thereby completing the model specification.

Parameters:

  • X (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame containing match features. It must include ‘home_id’ and ‘away_id’ columns that denote the identifiers for the home and away teams, respectively.

  • y (pd.Series) – The target data representing observed goal counts, provided as a pandas Series.

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments for customizing the model configuration, if necessary.
